content.raw:
After thinking about this a bit, my vote is to leave ```--include-coords``` and ```--validation-coords``` separate. Several reasons:

* Increases the complexity of the code and may slow down performance (eg requiring multiple intersections due to all the interacting coordinate parameters)
* The way ```--include-coords``` is calculated will need to be changed as either one of the following will no longer be possible: 1) held-out validation sets (if we do not remove the intersection of val/train from train set), 2) training sets and coordinate-chosen validation sets that overlap in any way (if we do force removal of the intersection of val/train from the train set). Leaving the two options separate will give users the freedom to choose the way their training sets and validation sets are related, separate of Segway
* From a user POV, having the ```--validation-coords``` you specified possibly not actually be the coordinates of your validation set due to requiring intersection with some other parameter is strange.

Any current ambiguity with the ```--help``` message could be clarified by changing the help message for both parameters to note that they are separate and don't interact. Eg ```--include-coords``` limits genomic coordinates for all tasks except validation-related ones.

update.title: Validation on holdout set

update.description:
Currently activated using either ```--minibatch-fraction``` and/or ```--validation-fraction```. If minibatch is used but the validation fraction is not specified, then the validation fraction will default to be the same as the minibatch fraction.

The validation set is chosen once, before training, from a random subset of the include coordinates satisfying the size given by the validation fraction. This subset is 'held out' from the training set. The remaining set of the include coords become the training windows.

Validation set creation and validation itself are queued and submitted through ```segway-task```.

If validation is on, then the winner will be chosen (for both fixed and minibatch) from the params set (across all instances) that gives the best posterior probability of evidence.

If the validation set consists of multiple validation windows, then the weight-normalised average (weighted based on size of each window) is taken to be the prob(evidence) for the entire set.

Segway file structure remains intact with some additions: ```observations/validation``` contains the observations files/lists for the validation set. 

```log``` folder now additionally contains the following .tab files:

* ```validation.output.xx.tab``` logs all validation windows, size, and prob(E) for each round for instance xx
* ```validation.weightedaverage.xx.tab``` logs the weighted average prob(E) for each round for instance xx

```likelihood``` folder now additionally contains the following .ll files:

* ```validation.output.xx.ll``` logs the last validation output for instance xx (note: this is the full gmtkJT output)
* ```validation.output.winner.xx.ll``` logs the so-far best validation output for instance xx
* ```validation.weightedaverage.xx.ll``` logs the last weighted prob(E) for instance xx
* ```validation.weightedaverage.winner.xx.ll``` logs the so-far best weighted prob(E) for instance xx

And finally, at the end, ```validation.output.ll``` and ```validation.weightedsum.ll``` will simply log the final best weighted prob(E) overall across all instances.
